Puberty (Puberty)  occurs through a long process and begins with a surge in hormone production, which in turn causes a number of physical changes. This is triggered by the pituitary gland, which secretes a surge of hormonal agents into the blood stream, initiating a chain reaction to occur. The male and female gonads (The male and female gonads)  are subsequently activated, which puts them (The male and female gonads)  into a state of rapid growth and development; the triggered gonads (The male and female gonads)  now commence the mass production of the necessary chemicals. The testes primarily release testosterone, and the ovaries predominantly dispense estrogen (estrogen) . Multimedia is content that uses a combination of different content forms such as text, audio, images, animations, video and interactive content. Multimedia contrasts with media that use only rudimentary computer displays such as text-only or traditional forms of printed or hand-produced material. 

Multimedia can be recorded and played, displayed, interacted with or accessed by information content processing devices, such as computerized and electronic devices, but can also be part of a live performance. Multimedia devices are electronic media devices used to store and experience multimedia content. The term "rich media" is synonymous with interactive multimedia.

Discogs, short for discographies, (Discogs, short for discographies,)  is a website and crowdsourced database of information about audio recordings, including commercial releases, promotional releases, and bootleg or off-label releases. The Discogs (Discogs, short for discographies,)  servers, currently hosted under the domain name discogs.com (the domain name discogs.com) , are owned by Zink Media, Inc. (Zink Media, Inc.) , and are located in Portland (Portland) , Oregon (Oregon) , US (US) . While the site (Discogs, short for discographies,)  lists releases in all genres and on all formats, it (Discogs, short for discographies,)  is especially known as the largest online database of electronic music releases, and of releases on vinyl media. Discogs (Discogs, short for discographies,)  currently contains over 8 million (8 million)  releases, by nearly 4.9 million (nearly 4.9 million)  artists, across over 1 million (1 million)  labels, contributed from nearly 346,000 (nearly 346,000)  contributor user accounts—with these figures constantly growing as users continually add previously unlisted releases to the site (Discogs, short for discographies,)  over time. 

The discogs.com domain name (the domain name discogs.com)  was registered on 30 August 2000 (30 August 2000) , and Discogs (Discogs, short for discographies,)  itself (Discogs, short for discographies,)  was launched in November 2000 (November 2000)  by programmer, DJ, and music fan Kevin Lewandowski (programmer, DJ, and music fan Kevin Lewandowski)  originally as a database of electronic music. 

He (programmer, DJ, and music fan Kevin Lewandowski)  was inspired by the success of community-built sites such as Slashdot (Slashdot) , eBay (eBay) , and Open Directory Project (Open Directory Project) , and decided to use this model for a music discography database. 

The site's (Discogs, short for discographies,)  original goal was to build the most comprehensive database of electronic music (electronic music) , organized around the artists, labels, and releases available in that genre (electronic music) . In 2003 (2003)  the Discogs (Discogs, short for discographies,)  system was completely rewritten, and in January 2004 (January 2004)  it (Discogs, short for discographies,)  began to support other genres, starting with hip hop. Since then, it (Discogs, short for discographies,)  has expanded to include rock and jazz in January 2005 (January 2005)  and funk/soul, Latin (Latin) , and reggae in October (October)  of the same year (January 2005) . Endemism is the ecological state of a species being unique to a defined geographic location, such as an island, nation, country or other defined zone, or habitat type; organisms that are indigenous to a place (a place)  (organisms that are indigenous to a place)  are not endemic to it (a place)  if they (organisms that are indigenous to a place)  are also found elsewhere. The extreme opposite of endemism is cosmopolitan distribution. An alternative term for a species that is endemic is precinctive, which applies to species (and subspecific categories) that are restricted to a defined geographical area. 

The word "endemic" is from New Latin (Latin)  "endēmicus", from Greek (Greek)  ενδήμος, "endēmos", "native". "Endēmos (Endēmos) " is formed of "en" meaning "in", and "dēmos" meaning "the people". It (The term "precinctive")  is the equivalent of "endemism". "Precinction" was perhaps first (first)  used by Frank (Frank)  and McCoy (McCoy) . 'precinctive forms' means those forms that are confined to the area specified." That definition excludes artificial confinement of examples by humans in far-off botanical gardens or zoological parks. 

Physical, climatic, and biological factors can contribute to endemism. A One (One)  Day International (ODI) is a form of limited overs cricket, played between two (two)  teams with international status, in which each team faces a fixed number of overs, usually 50 (50) . The Cricket World Cup (The Cricket World Cup)  is played in this format. One Day International matches (One Day International matches)  are also called (called)  Limited Overs Internationals (Limited Overs Internationals)  (LOI (LOI) ), although this generic term (called)  may also refer to Twenty20 International matches. They (One Day International matches)  are major matches and considered the highest standard of List A (List A) , limited overs competition. 

The international one-day (one-day)  game is a late twentieth-century (twentieth-century)  development. The first ODI (The first ODI)  was played on 5 January 1971 (5 January 1971)  between Australia (Australia)  and England (England)  at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (the Melbourne Cricket Ground) . When the first three days of the (the first three days of the)  third (third)  Test were washed out officials decided to abandon the match (The first ODI)  and, instead, play a one (one) -off one day (one day)  game consisting of 40 eight (40 eight) -ball overs per side. Australia (Australia)  won the game (The first ODI)  by 5 (5)  wickets. ODIs were played in white kits with a red ball. 

In the late 1970s (the late 1970s) , Kerry Packer (Kerry Packer)  established the rival World Series Cricket competition (the rival World Series Cricket competition) , and it (the rival World Series Cricket competition)  introduced many of the features of One (One)  Day International (Day International)  cricket that are now commonplace, including coloured uniforms, matches played at night (night)  under floodlights with a white ball and dark sight screens, and, for television broadcasts, multiple camera angles, effects microphones to capture sounds from the players on the pitch, and on-screen graphics. The first of the matches with coloured uniforms (The first of the matches with coloured uniforms)  was the WSC Australians (Australians)  in wattle gold versus WSC (WSC)  West Indians (West Indians)  in coral pink, played at VFL Park (VFL Park)  in Melbourne (Melbourne)  on 17 January 1979 (17 January 1979) . This (The first of the matches with coloured uniforms)  led not only to Kerry Packer's (Kerry Packer)  Channel 9 (Channel 9)  getting the TV rights to cricket in Australia (Australia)  but also led to players worldwide being paid to play, and becoming international professionals, no longer needing jobs outside cricket. Matches played with coloured kits and a white ball became more commonplace over time, and the use of white flannels and a red ball in ODIs (ODIs)  was finally abandoned in 2001 (2001) .

Various Germanic tribes)  expanded southward. Beginning in the 10th century (the 10th century) , German (German)  territories formed a central part of the Holy Roman Empire (the Holy Roman Empire) . During the 16th century (the 16th century) , northern German (German)  regions became the centre of the Protestant Reformation (the Protestant Reformation) . After the collapse of the Holy Roman Empire (the Holy Roman Empire) , the German Confederation (the German Confederation)  was formed in 1815 (1815) . The German (German)  revolutions of 1848–49 resulted in the Frankfurt Parliament (Frankfurt Parliament)  establishing major democratic rights. 

In 1871 (1871) , Germany (Germany)  became a nation state when most of the German (German)  states unified into the Prussian-dominated German Empire (the Holy Roman Empire) . After World War I (World War I)  and the German Revolution of 1918–19, the Empire (the Holy Roman Empire)  was replaced by the parliamentary Weimar Republic (Weimar Republic) . In 1933 (1933)  the Nazi (Nazi)  seizure of power quickly led to the establishment of Nazi (Nazi)  Germany (Germany)  which was built upon a dictatorship and consequently led to World War II (World War I)  and the Holocaust (Holocaust) . After the end of (the end of)  World War II (World War I)  in Europe (Europe)  and a period of Allied (Allied)  occupation, two (two)  German (German)  states were founded: the democratic West Germany (West Germany)  and the socialist East Germany (East Germany) . Following the Revolutions of 1989 (1989)  that ended communist rule in Central and Eastern Europe (Central and Eastern Europe) , the country (Germany)  was reunified on 3 October 1990 (3 October 1990) .

Representative democracy (Representative democracy)  (also indirect democracy, representative republic, or psephocracy) is a type of democracy founded on the principle of elected officials representing a group of people, as opposed to direct democracy. Nearly all modern Western-style democracies are types of representative democracies; for example, the United Kingdom (the United Kingdom)  is a constitutional monarchy, Ireland (Ireland)  is a unitary parliamentary republic, and the United States (the United States)  is a federal republic.

It (Representative democracy)  has been described by some political theorists including Robert A. Dahl (Robert A. Dahl) , Gregory Houston (Gregory Houston)  and Ian Liebenberg (Ian Liebenberg)  as polyarchy. In it (Representative democracy)  the power is in the hands of the elected representatives who are elected by the people in elections. 

Representatives are elected by the public, as in national elections for the national legislature. Elected representatives may hold the power to select other representatives, presidents, or other officers of the government or of the legislature, as the Prime Minister in the latter case. (indirect representation).

Pain (Pain)  is a distressing feeling often caused by intense or damaging stimuli, such as stubbing a toe, burning a finger, putting alcohol on a cut, and bumping the "funny bone". Because it (Pain)  is a complex, subjective phenomenon, defining pain has been a challenge. The International Association for the Study of Pain's (The International Association for the Study of Pain's)  widely used definition states: "Pain is an unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage." In medical diagnosis, pain is a symptom. 

Pain (Pain)  is the most common reason for physician consultation in most developed countries. It (Pain)  is a major symptom in many medical conditions, and can interfere with a person's quality of life and general functioning. Psychological factors such as social support, hypnotic suggestion, excitement, or distraction can significantly affect pain's intensity or unpleasantness. In some arguments put forth in physician-assisted suicide or euthanasia debates, pain has been used as an argument to permit terminally ill patients (terminally ill patients)  to end their (terminally ill patients)  lives.

An atoll (, , , , or ), sometimes called a coral atoll (An atoll (, , , , or ), sometimes called a coral atoll) , is a ring-shaped coral reef including a coral rim that encircles a lagoon (a coral rim that encircles a lagoon)  (a lagoon)  partially or completely. The lagoon (a lagoon)  forms over the volcanic crater or caldera while the higher rim remains above water or at shallow depths that permit the coral (The coral of the atoll)  to grow and form the reefs. For the atoll (An atoll (, , , , or ), sometimes called a coral atoll)  to persist, continued erosion or subsidence must be at a rate slow enough to permit reef growth upwards and outwards to replace the lost height.

Wool is the textile fiber obtained from sheep and other animals, including cashmere and mohair from goats, qiviut from muskoxen (muskoxen) , angora from rabbits, and other types of wool from camelids. These follicles (follicles which are small cells located in the skin)  are located in the upper layer of the skin called the epidermis and push down into the second (second)  skin layer called the dermis as the wool fibers grow. Follicles can be classed as either primary or secondary follicles. Primary follicles produce three (three)  types of fiber: kemp, medullated fibers (medullated fibers)  and true wool fibers. Secondary follicles only produce true wool fibers. Medullated fibers (medullated fibers)  share nearly identical characteristics to hair and are long but lack crimp and elasticity. Kemp fibers are very coarse and shed out. Wool (Wool) 's scaling and crimp make it easier to spin the fleece by helping the individual fibers (the individual fibers)  attach to each other, so they (the individual fibers)  stay together. Because of the crimp, wool fabrics (wool fabrics)  have greater bulk than other textiles, and they (wool fabrics)  hold air, which causes the fabric (Wool)  to retain heat. Wool (Wool)  has a high specific heat coefficient, so it (Wool)  impedes heat transfer in general. The National Assembly for Wales (The National Assembly for Wales)  (; commonly known as the Welsh Assembly (the Welsh Assembly) ) is a devolved assembly with power to make legislation in Wales (Wales) . The Assembly (The National Assembly for Wales)  comprises 60 (60)  members, who are known as Assembly Members (Assembly Members) , or AMs ("Aelodau y Cynulliad (Aelodau y Cynulliad) "). Since 2011 (2011) , Members are elected for five-year (five-year)  terms under an additional members system, in which 40 (40)  AMs represent geographical constituencies elected by the plurality system, and 20 (20)  AMs represent five (five)  electoral regions using the d'Hondt (d'Hondt)  method of proportional representation. 

The Assembly (The National Assembly for Wales)  was created by the Government of Wales Act 1998 (the Government of Wales Act 1998) , which followed a referendum in 1997 (1997) . The Assembly (The National Assembly for Wales)  had no powers to initiate primary legislation until limited law-making powers (limited law-making powers)  were gained through the Government of Wales Act 2006 (the Government of Wales Act 2006) . Its (The National Assembly for Wales)  primary law-making powers (limited law-making powers)  were enhanced following a Yes vote in the referendum on 3 March 2011 (3 March 2011) , making it possible for it (The National Assembly for Wales)  to legislate without having to consult the UK (UK)  parliament or the Secretary of State (State)  for Wales in the 20 (20)  areas that are devolved. 

An appointed Council for Wales (Wales)  and Monmouthshire (An appointed Council for Wales and Monmouthshire)  was established in 1949 (1949)  to "ensure the government is adequately informed of the impact of government activities on the general life of the people of Wales (Wales) ". The council (An appointed Council for Wales and Monmouthshire)  had 27 (27)  members nominated by local authorities in Wales (Wales) , the University of Wales (the University of Wales) , National Eisteddfod Council (National Eisteddfod Council)  and the Welsh Tourist Board (the Welsh Tourist Board) . A post of Minister of Welsh Affairs (Welsh Affairs)  was created in 1951 (1951)  and the post of Secretary of State (State)  for Wales and the Welsh Office (the Welsh Office)  were established in 1964 (1964)  leading to the abolition of the Council for Wales (the Council for Wales) . The establishment of the Welsh Office (the Welsh Office)  effectively created the basis for the territorial governance of Wales (Wales) . The Royal Commission on the Constitution (The Royal Commission on the Constitution)  (the Kilbrandon Commission (the Kilbrandon Commission) ) was set up in 1969 (1969)  by Harold Wilson's (Harold Wilson's)  Labour Government (Labour Government)  to investigate the possibility of devolution for Scotland (Scotland)  and Wales (Wales) . Its (The Royal Commission on the Constitution)  recommendations formed the basis of the 1974 (1974)  White Paper "Democracy and Devolution (Democracy and Devolution) : proposals for Scotland (Scotland)  and Wales (Wales) ", which proposed (proposed)  the creation of a Welsh Assembly (a Welsh Assembly) . However, voters rejected the proposals (proposed)  by a majority of four (four)  to one in a referendum held in 1979 (1979) .

Climate (Climate)  is the statistics of weather over long periods of time. It (Climate)  is measured by assessing the patterns of variation in temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, precipitation, atmospheric particle count and other meteorological variables in a given region over long periods of time (the patterns of variation in temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, precipitation, atmospheric particle count and other meteorological variables in a given region over long periods of time) . Climate differs from weather, in that weather only describes the short-term conditions of these variables (the patterns of variation in temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, precipitation, atmospheric particle count and other meteorological variables in a given region over long periods of time)  in a given region. 

A region's climate is generated by the climate system, which has five (five)  components: atmosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere. 

The climate of a location (a location)  is affected by its (a location)  latitude, terrain, and altitude, as well as nearby water bodies (nearby water bodies)  and their (nearby water bodies)  currents. Climates can be classified according to the average and the typical ranges of different variables, most commonly temperature and precipitation. The most commonly used classification scheme was the Köppen (Köppen)  climate classification. The Thornthwaite (Thornthwaite)  system, in use since 1948 (1948) , incorporates evapotranspiration along with temperature and precipitation information and is used in studying biological diversity (biological diversity)  and how climate change affects it (biological diversity) . The Bergeron (Bergeron)  and Spatial Synoptic Classification (Spatial Synoptic Classification)  systems focus on the origin of air masses that define the climate of a region. 

Paleoclimatology is the study of ancient climates. Since direct observations of climate are not available before the 19th century (the 19th century) , paleoclimates are inferred from proxy variables that include non-biotic evidence such as sediments found in lake beds and ice cores, and biotic evidence such as tree rings and coral. Climate models are mathematical models of past, present and future climates. Climate change may occur over long and short timescales from a variety of factors; recent warming is discussed in global warming. Global warming results in redistributions. For example, "a 3 (3) °C change in mean annual (annual)  temperature corresponds to a shift in isotherms of approximately 300–400 km (approximately 300–400 km)  in latitude (in the temperate zone) or 500 (500)  m in elevation. Therefore, species are expected to move upwards in elevation or towards the poles in latitude in response to shifting climate zones".

A gene is a locus (or region) of DNA that encodes a functional RNA (RNA)  or protein product, and is the molecular unit of heredity.:Glossary The transmission of genes to an organism's offspring is the basis of the inheritance of phenotypic traits. Most biological traits are under the influence of polygenes (many different genes) as well as the gene–environment interactions. Some genetic traits are instantly visible, such as eye colour or number of limbs, and some are not, such as blood type, risk for specific diseases, or the thousands (thousands)  of basic biochemical processes that comprise life. 

Genes (Genes)  can acquire mutations in their (Genes)  sequence, leading to different variants, known as alleles, in the population (different variants, known as alleles, in the population) . These alleles (different variants, known as alleles, in the population)  encode slightly different versions of a protein, which cause different phenotype traits. Colloquial usage of the term "having a gene" (e.g., "good genes," "hair colour gene") typically refers to having a different allele of the gene. Genes evolve due to natural selection or survival of the fittest of the alleles.

A social class (or, simply, class), as in class society, is a set of subjectively defined concepts in the social sciences and political theory centered on models of social stratification in which people are grouped into a set of hierarchical social categories, the most common being the upper, middle, and lower classes. 

Class (Class)  is a subject of analysis for sociologists, political scientists, anthropologists, and social historians. However, there is not a consensus on a definition of "class", and the term (Class)  has a wide range of sometimes conflicting meanings. In common parlance, the term "social class" (Class)  is usually synonymous with "socio-economic class", defined as "people having the same social, economic, cultural, political or educational status", e.g., "the working class"; "an emerging professional class". However, academics distinguish social class (social class)  and socioeconomic status (socioeconomic status) , with the former (social class)  referring to one’s relatively stable sociocultural background and the latter (socioeconomic status)  referring to one (one) ’s current social and economic situation and, consequently, being more changeable over time. 

The precise measurements of what determines social class in society has varied over time. Karl Marx (Karl Marx)  thought "class" was defined by one's relationship to the means of production (their relations of production). His (Karl Marx)  simple understanding of classes in modern capitalist society, are the proletariat, those who work but do not own the means of production (the proletariat, those who work but do not own the means of production) ; and the bourgeoisie, those who invest and live off of the surplus generated by the former (the proletariat, those who work but do not own the means of production) . This contrasts with the view of the sociologist Max Weber (Max Weber) , who argued "class" is determined by economic position, in contrast to "social status" or ""Stand"" which is determined by social prestige rather than simply just relations of production.

Leeds (Leeds)  is a city in West Yorkshire (West Yorkshire) , England (England) . Historically in Yorkshire's (West Yorkshire)  West Riding (West Yorkshire) , the history of Leeds (Leeds)  can be traced to the 5th century (the 5th century) , when the name (the name)  referred to a wooded area of the Kingdom of Elmet (the Kingdom of Elmet) . The name (the name)  has been applied to many administrative entities over the centuries (the centuries) . It (the name)  changed from being the name of a small manorial borough in the 13th century (the 13th century) , through several incarnations, to being the name attached to the present metropolitan borough. In the 17th and 18th centuries (the 17th and 18th centuries)  Leeds (Leeds)  became a major centre for the production and trading of wool. 

During the Industrial Revolution (the Industrial Revolution) , Leeds (Leeds)  developed into a major mill town; wool was the dominant industry but flax, engineering, iron foundries, printing, and other industries were important. From being a compact market town in the valley of the River Aire (the River Aire)  in the 16th century (the 16th century)  Leeds (Leeds)  expanded and absorbed the surrounding villages to become a populous urban centre by the mid-20th century (the mid-20th century) . Leeds (Leeds)  has a population of around 781,700 (around 781,700)  (2016 (2016) ) making it (Leeds)  the third (third)  largest city in the United Kingdom (England) . The city (Leeds)  lies within the United Kingdom's (England)  fourth (fourth) -most populous urban area, with a population of 2.3 million (2.3 million) . 

Today (Today) , Leeds (Leeds)  has the most diverse economy of all the UK's (England)  main employment centres and has seen the fastest rate of private-sector jobs growth of any UK (UK)  city and has the highest ratio of public to private sector jobs of all the UK's (England)  Core Cities (Core Cities) . Leeds (Leeds)  has the third (third) -largest jobs total by local authority area with 480,000 (480,000)  in employment and self-employment at the beginning of 2015 (the beginning of 2015) . Leeds (Leeds)  is also ranked as a gamma world city by the Globalization and World Cities Research Network (the Globalization and World Cities Research Network) ; and is considered the cultural, financial and commercial heart of the West Yorkshire Urban Area (the West Yorkshire Urban Area) . Leeds (Leeds)  is served by four (four)  universities, and has the fourth (fourth)  largest student population in the country (England)  and has the country's (England)  fourth (fourth)  largest urban economy.

Myocardial infarction (MI) or acute myocardial infarction (AMI (AMI) ), commonly known as a heart attack, occurs when blood flow stops to a part of the heart causing damage to the heart muscle. The most common symptom is chest pain or discomfort which may travel into the shoulder, arm, back, neck, or jaw (chest pain or discomfort which may travel into the shoulder, arm, back, neck, or jaw) . Often it (chest pain or discomfort which may travel into the shoulder, arm, back, neck, or jaw)  is in the center or left side of the chest and lasts for more than a few minutes (a few minutes) . The discomfort (chest pain or discomfort which may travel into the shoulder, arm, back, neck, or jaw)  may occasionally feel like heartburn. Other symptoms may include shortness of breath, nausea, feeling faint, a cold sweat, or feeling tired. About 30% (About 30%)  of people have atypical symptoms, with women more likely than men to present atypically. Among those over 75 years old (75 years old) , about 5% (about 5%)  have had an MI with little or no history of symptoms. An MI may cause heart failure, an irregular heartbeat, or cardiac arrest. 

Most MIs occur due to coronary artery disease. Risk factors include high blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, lack of exercise, obesity, high blood cholesterol, poor diet, and excessive alcohol intake, among others. The mechanism of an MI often involves the complete blockage of a coronary artery caused by a rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque. MIs are less commonly caused by coronary artery spasms, which may be due to cocaine, significant emotional stress, and extreme cold, among others. A number of tests are useful to help with diagnosis, including electrocardiograms (ECGs), blood tests, and coronary angiography. An ECG (ECG)  may confirm an ST (ST)  elevation MI if ST (ST)  elevation is present. Commonly used blood tests include troponin and less often creatine kinase MB (MB) .

Futsal (Futsal) , (literally "mini-football", "futebol de salão" i.e. "big room soccer"), is a variant of association football played on a hard court, smaller than a football pitch, and mainly indoors. It (Futsal)  can be considered a version of five (five) -a-side football. 

Futsal (Futsal)  is played between two (two)  teams of five (five)  players each, one of whom is the goalkeeper. Unlimited substitutions are permitted. Unlike some other forms of indoor football, the game (Futsal)  is played on a hard court surface delimited by lines; walls or boards are not used. Futsal (Futsal)  is also played with a smaller ball. The surface, ball, and rules create an emphasis on improvisation, creativity, and technique as well as ball control and passing in small spaces. 

"Futsal (Futsal) " comes from Spanish (Spanish)  "fútbol sala or fútbol de salón" and from Portuguese (Portuguese)  "futebol de salão". The term (Futsal)  is commonly translated as "indoor football" but a more literal translation is "hall/lounge football". During the sport's (Futsal)  second (second)  world championships held in Madrid (Madrid)  in 1985 (1985) , the Spanish (Spanish)  name "fútbol sala" was used (used) . Since then, all other names have been officially and internationally changed to "futsal". The naming (used)  was due to a dispute between FIFUSA (the predecessor to the AMF (FIFUSA (the predecessor to the AMF) ) and FIFA (FIFA)  over the name of "fútbol", FIFUSA (FIFUSA (the predecessor to the AMF)  has registered the word "fut-sal" in 1985 (1985)  (Madrid, Spain (Madrid) ). Since then FIFA (FIFA)  has also started using the term futsal (Futsal) . The Oxford Dictionary (Oxford Dictionary)  suggests the name (The term)  to be a blend of the words gene and chromosome. However, see omics for a more thorough discussion. A few related -ome words already existed—such as biome, rhizome, forming a vocabulary into which genome fits systematically. 

Some organisms have multiple copies of chromosomes: diploid (diploid) , triploid, tetraploid and so on. In classical genetics, in a sexually reproducing organism (typically eukarya) the gamete has half (half)  the number of chromosomes of the somatic cell and the genome is a full set of chromosomes in a diploid cell. The halving of the genetic material in gametes is accomplished by the segregation of homologous chromosomes during meiosis. In haploid organisms, including cells of bacteria, archaea, and in organelles including mitochondria and chloroplasts, or viruses, that similarly contain genes, the single or set of circular or linear (linear)  chains of DNA (or RNA (RNA)  for some viruses), likewise constitute the genome. The term genome can be applied specifically to mean what is stored on a complete set of nuclear DNA (i.e., the "nuclear genome") but can also be applied to what is stored within organelles that contain their own DNA (organelles that contain their own DNA)  (organelles that contain their own DNA) , as with the "mitochondrial genome" or the "chloroplast genome". Additionally, the genome (the genome)  can comprise non-chromosomal genetic elements such as viruses, plasmids, and transposable elements.

Consequently, Weinreich (Weinreich)  gives the definition "A person's identity (the definition "A person's identity)  is defined as the totality of one's self-construal, in which how one (one)  construes oneself in the present expresses the continuity between how one (one)  construes oneself as one was in the past and how one (one)  construes oneself as one (one)  aspires to be in the future"; this (the definition "A person's identity)  allows for definitions of aspects of identity, such as: "One's ethnic identity is defined as that part of the totality of one's self-construal made up of those dimensions that express the continuity between one's construal of past ancestry and one's future aspirations in relation to ethnicity" (Weinreich, 1986a (Weinreich) ). 

The description or representation of individual and group identity is a central task for psychologists, sociologists and anthropologists and those of other disciplines where "identity" needs to be mapped and defined. How should one (one)  describe the identity of another (another) , in ways which encompass both their (another)  idiosyncratic qualities and their (another)  group memberships or identifications, both of which can shift according to circumstance? Following on from the work of Kelly (Kelly) , Erikson (Erikson) , Tajfel and others Weinreich (Weinreich) 's Identity Structure Analysis (ISA (Identity Structure Analysis (ISA) ), is "a structural representation of the individual's existential experience, in which the relationships between self and other agents are organised in relatively stable structures over time … with the emphasis on the socio-cultural milieu in which self relates to other agents and institutions" (Weinreich (Weinreich)  and Saunderson (Saunderson) , (eds) 2003 (2003) , p1). Using constructs drawn from the salient discourses of the individual, the group and cultural norms (constructs drawn from the salient discourses of the individual, the group and cultural norms) , the practical operationalisation of ISA (Identity Structure Analysis (ISA)  provides a methodology that maps how these (constructs drawn from the salient discourses of the individual, the group and cultural norms)  are used by the individual, applied across time and milieus by the "situated self" to appraise self and other agents and institutions (for example, resulting in the individual's evaluation of self and significant others and institutions).[citation needed]

A440 or A4 (also known as the Stuttgart pitch), which has a frequency of 440 Hz (A440 or A4 (also known as the Stuttgart pitch), which has a frequency of 440 Hz) , is the musical note of A above middle C and serves as a general tuning standard for musical pitch.
